hyperlearn package¶

Submodules¶

hyperlearn.base module¶

hyperlearn.linalg module¶

hyperlearn.linalg.dot(A, B, C, message=False)[source]¶

Implements fast matrix multiplication of 3 matrices X = ABC From left: X = (AB)C. From right: X = A(BC). This function calculates which is faster, and outputs the result. [Added 10/12/18] [Edited 13/12/18 Added left or right statement] [Edited 20/12/18 Uses numba]

Parameters:
  • A (First matrix)
  • B (Multiplied with 2nd matrix)
  • C (Multiplied with 3rd matrix)
  • message (Default = False. If True, doesn’t output result, but) – outputs TRUE if left to right, else FALSE right to left.
Returns:
Return type:

(A@B@C or message)
hyperlearn.linalg.matmul(pattern, X, Y=None)[source]¶

Using BLAS routines GEMM, SYRK, SYMM, multiplies 2 matrices together assuming X has some special structure or the output is special. Supports symmetric constructions: X.H @ X and X @ X.H; symmetric multiplies: S @ Y.H and Y.H @ S where S is a symmetric matrix; general multiplies: X @ Y and X.H @ Y. [Added 28/11/18 Changed from transpose since it didn’t work] [Edited 1/12/18 Added S @ Y] [Edited 17/12/18 Added Y @ S]

Parameters:
  • pattern (Can include: X.H @ X | X @ X.H | S @ Y.H |) – Y.H @ S | X @ Y | X.H @ Y | S @ Y | Y @ S
  • X (Compulsory left side matrix.)
  • Y (Optional right side matrix.)
Returns:

out
Return type:

Special matrix output according to pattern.
hyperlearn.linalg.transpose(X, overwrite=True, dtype=None)[source]¶

Provides X.T if dtype == float, else X.H (Conjugate transpose) [Added 23/11/18]

Parameters:
  • X (Matrix to be decomposed. Has to be symmetric.)
  • Overwrite (If overwritten, then inplace operation.)
Returns:

X.T or X.H
Return type:

Conjugate Tranpose (X)

hyperlearn.utils.add_jitter[source]¶

Epsilon Jitter Algorithm from Modern Big Data Algorithms. Forces certain algorithms to converge via ridge regularization. [Added 15/11/18] [Edited 25/11/18 for floating point errors] [Edited 21/12/18 first pass checks what should be added]

hyperlearn.utils.diag_set[source]¶

Sets the diagonal of a square matrix X to new. [Added 5/1/19]

hyperlearn.utils.do_until_success(f, epsilon_f, size, overwrite=False, alpha=None, *args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Epsilon Jitter Algorithm from Modern Big Data Algorithms. Forces certain algorithms to converge via ridge regularization. [Added 15/11/18] [Edited 25/11/18 Fixed Alpha setting, can now run in approx 1 - 2 runs] [Edited 26/11/18 99% rounded accuracy in 1 run] [Edited 14/12/18 Some overwrite errors] [Edited 21/12/18 If see a 0]

Parameters:
  • f (Function for solver)
  • epsilon_f (How to add epsilon)
  • size (Argument for epsilon_f)
  • overwrite (Whether to overwrite data matrix)
  • alpha (Ridge regularizer - default = 1e-6)
hyperlearn.utils.eig_condition(X, W, V)[source]¶
hyperlearn.utils.eig_search[source]¶

Corrects the eigenvalues if they’re smaller than 0.

hyperlearn.utils.eigh_search[source]¶
hyperlearn.utils.frobenius_norm(X, symmetric=False)[source]¶

Outputs the ||X||_F ^ 2 norm of a matrix. If symmetric, then computes the norm on 1/2 of the matrix and multiplies it by 2.

hyperlearn.utils.gram_schmidt[source]¶

Modified stable Gram Schmidt process. Gram-Schmidt Orthogonalization Instructor: Ana Rita Pires (MIT 18.06SC). Output is Q.T NOT Q. So you must transpose it.

hyperlearn.utils.normA[source]¶
hyperlearn.utils.proportion[source]¶
hyperlearn.utils.reflect(X)[source]¶
hyperlearn.utils.row_norm(X)[source]¶
hyperlearn.utils.sign_max(X, axis=0, n_jobs=1)[source]¶

[Added 19/11/2018] [Edited 24/11/2018 Uses NUMBA] Returns the sign of the maximum absolute value of an axis of X.

X: Matrix X to be processed. Must be 2D array. axis: Default = 0. 0 = column-wise. 1 = row-wise. n_jobs: Default = 1. Uses multiple CPUs if n*p > 20,000^2.

hyperlearn.utils.svd_condition(U, S, VT, alpha=None)[source]¶

[Added 21/11/2018] Uses Scipy’s SVD condition number calculation to improve pseudoinverse stability. Uses (1e3, 1e6) * eps(S) * S[0] as the condition number. Everythimg below cond is set to 0.

U: U matrix from SVD S: S diagonal array from SVD VT: VT matrix (V transpose) from SVD alpha: Default = None. Ridge regularization

hyperlearn.utils.svd_flip(U=None, VT=None, U_decision=False, n_jobs=1)[source]¶

[Added 19/11/2018] [Edited 24/11/2018 Uses NUMBA] Flips the signs of U and VT from a SVD or eigendecomposition. Default opposite to Sklearn’s U decision. HyperLearn uses the maximum of rows of VT.

U: U matrix from SVD VT: VT matrix (V transpose) from SVD U_decision: Default = False. If True, uses max from U.

hyperlearn.utils.svd_search[source]¶

Determines the rank of a matrix via the singular values. (Counts how many are larger than eps.)

hyperlearn.utils.triu[source]¶
hyperlearn.utils.unique_int(a, return_counts=False)[source]¶

Given a list of postive ints, returns the unique elements accompanied with optional counts. [Added 23/12/18]

Parameters:
  • a (Array of postive ints)
  • return_counts (Whether to return (unique, counts))
hyperlearn.utils.unique_sorted(a, return_counts=False)[source]¶

Given a list of sorted elements, returns the unique elements accompanied with optional counts. [Added 23/12/18]

Parameters:
  • a (Array of sorted elements)
  • return_counts (Whether to return (unique, counts))
